results.content:
My previous experience with Wordpress was very limited and disorganised, so I felt I could really benefit from a more rigorous approach to theme development. I learned a lot of very useful info about building WP themes, which I probably wouldn't have discovered so quickly if I hadn't taken this course.  
I'm a frontend developer so I skipped the CSS styling parts of the course, but I can understand they are quite valuable for others. Overall, this is a very useful course for me, as a beginner in WP theme development. I know the realm of Wordpress is quite complex and can look overwhelming at first, but with a starter course like this one, I feel I'm on the right track :)

results.content:
The instructor is clearly knowledgeable about the course material and he teaches the material in a straightforward way that is easy to understand and follow. The instruction is very hands-on, which is perfect.

My only issue with the course is that the WordPress-specific material is overshadowed by introductory web design. Juan assumes that you have a solid understanding of web development, but then spends hours walking you through creating content that has nothing to do with WordPress itself. I feel a better format would be to curate or provide an existing static website that could be converted to WordPress to avoid hours of tedious content creation, but this course is still quite good regardless.

results.content:
In a world full of 'WordPress' developers who charge big bucks then install a "Swiss Army Knife' theme from Theme Forest my motivation is to get back to basics and build WordPress sites from an absolute blank canvas, only using what's necessary for the specific site, and avoiding the constant reverse engineering that comes from adopting someone else's opinion of how things should be done. This course provides exactly that approach.
The only slight criticism is that the material dates slightly now we have FlexBox and CSS Grid available, and WordPress will 'evolve' significantly with the introduction of the Gutenberg editor...having said that, we still need to know how to style fallbacks for older browsers...
results.content_html:

results.content:
The instruction was clear. The biggest problem I had was debugging my code and I often found that the problem was due to forgetting a comma or semi colon somewhere.
I did notice that the instructor does not answer questions, but I had enough support from other students and from seeking out answers online to get through the course.
I did watch all the videos and I coded the first project. I am in the process of coding the other three projects now, but I have learned enough so far to get a part time job working on an attorney's WordPress site. My being hired was contingent on finishing some kind of course and I also received the recommendation by referral. I also think having past work to show and offering a rate lower than what most US based developers with experience helped to. Nevertheless, I am working and gaining experience. I will say that this course is a great introduction because I'm using what I learned on the job, but it is not exhaustive and you will run into problems in the wild that you may have to research on your own. I still highly recommend this course for people with no WordPress experience.

results.content:
For me, this WP development from Scratch video course is priceless.  Since I am a WP newbie, I was searching for an online video to help better grasp of WP development at a core foundation.   Having 4 WP projects to follow along with the instructor, it help reinforced my understanding of WP hierarchy, page template, the WP loop, the inner working of the WP dashboard, plugins and much more.  
I truly recommend this course for newbie looking to get into WP development.  But I do suggest that you need to be comfortable with HTML and CSS at least.
Also the instructor is responsive to my questions but it does take some time for him to get back so far he has gotten back to me in a reasonable amount of time.   
I am hoping in the future he will create advanced WP development projects that has API calls, JSON involvement, child theme development or even create a user secure login WP site. 
Thank you so much Juan.

results.content:
I've been working with WordPress as a developer for about 10 years, mostly building child themes.  In the last year, I've muddled my way through learning to build custom plug-ins and building new themes from starter themes.

I wish I'd have taken this course 5 years ago. Everything makes sense now whereas before I felt like I had a hundred puzzle pieces and it felt like they were in the right place, but I just wasn't sure.

I'm only 15% into the course at this point, but I keep having these holy sh*t moments where I see what I've been doing the hard way and it all clicks!

I'll probably never do another child theme or use a starter theme as a base again.  Analyzing and extending others' code is much harder than the techniques Jaun teaches you here.

Amazing.

results.content: I couldn't be more thankful to you, Pablo De la torre Valdez! I had first started trying to get to grips with WordPress theming by following YouTube videos about a year ago, but there came a point when I found things confusing or inconclusive as to best practices. Then I tried courses (one of them by Morten Rand-Hendriksen, senior Wordpress guy, the course was Building Themes from Scratch using Underscores) on Lynda on my employer's subscription, and again I was overwhelmed. I'm willing to learn all the recommended stuff in time, like using scss instead css, and so on and so forth, but I can't do it all at once. So with those courses over there: there was automation strewn in, and all sorts of things ... and all of that, while not being fully up-to-date (vital links didn't work). Even if it sounds cheesy, but only when I took this course, I finally began to see the light :-) ... Things I had come across in other courses before began to make sense. Where it mattered that the course was written over 2 years ago (duplicater plugin and conversion issues to PHP7?) I repaired things with manual updates, or, for Bootstrap 4 instead of 3, I used an online conversion tool (which was quick, and only necessary for a few classes; the one I used was: http://upgrade-bootstrap.bootply.com/). All in all: I absolutely loved the course!

results.content:
I already know and use PHP, but I went through some of his basics to see how the course was. I think this is one of the best instructors I've ever seen. He is really knowledgeable, more than it might appear at first. But he really knows his stuff. Just the small things he says, while going over simple concepts, are so crucial for any learner. He might say something like, break up a for loop like this, or there are two methods of using PHP. No one else ever mentions this sort of thing early on and it's good to know.
Instructor also has a calm, deep, speaking voice that is relaxing, yet engaging at the same time. He makes you want to keep listening.
I feel confident moving forward in learning how to create themes the RIGHT way. Creating themes from scratch is different from learning wordpress and I looked through the chapters of this course. IT's exactly what you need even just beyond a beginner level.

results.content:
I'm about 40% of the way through the course and so far it's been amazing. 

My experience prior to this has mainly involved fumbling my way through customisation of pre-built themes, or using page builder themes, but I already feel confident that I'd be able to build a theme from scratch. Most of the different features I'd want to implement in a WordPress theme have already been covered. 

This course also has a section that covers creating a custom database for reservations and how to create a page in the WordPress backend to view them which I thought was a huge bonus.

Juan teaches at a medium pace and for the most part covers all topics in enough depth. There were a couple of instances where I needed to look at other resources (e.g. Codex, etc.) for extra clarity on a concept/function, but I think having a bit of a DYOR mindset is necessary in this industry anyway. 

Looking forward to the rest of the course!
